member.name: M:System.Net.Sockets.SocketExtensions.ReceiveUntilCompleted(System.Net.Sockets.Socket)
member.summary: Receives data from a bound into a sequence of arrays until the host shuts down the connection.

remarks.alert: Unlike many of the other methods, returns a cold observable. This is to ensure that observers do not miss any of the byte arrays in the sequence; otherwise, buffering would be required for the entire sequence, similar to how buffers the first result and then replays it to all subscribers. Another consequence of the cold behavior is that subscriptions are not shared, thus every new subscription will perform an independent receive operation on the .

member.param: The socket that will receive the data.
member.returns: An observable sequence of arrays containing the data that was received.

member.name: T:System.Linq.ICursor`1
member.summary: Represents a shared enumerable sequence that replays values from a current index that can be moved, along with support for optimized branching.

remarks.alert: The contracts of rely on some of the properties being immutable. The property must be immutable. Furthermore, the property must be until the sequence terminates, at which time it must return and then hold that value indefinitely.

member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.

member.name: M:System.Linq.ICursor`1.Move(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the current index of the cursor to the element at the specified number of elements forward or backward.
member.param: The number of elements to move after the current index if the specified count is positive or before the current index if the specified count is negative.

remarks.para: The specified may be a negative number only if is .
remarks.alert: If the specified is greater than the length from the current element to the latest element in the sequence, then the cursor must virtualize itself by skipping subsequent elements until the position of the cursor is reached.

member.name: M:System.Linq.ICursor`1.Branch
member.summary: Returns a new cursor that starts at the current position of this cursor and is tied to the lifetime of this cursor.

remarks.alert: provides a means for cursor authors to optimize branches so that they can share the same state.

member.returns: A new cursor that starts at the current position of this cursor.

member.name: M:System.Linq.ICursor`1.Reset
member.summary: Clears any buffered elements, branches and state, and ensures that a subsequent iteration will re-enumerate the source sequence.

member.name: P:System.Linq.ICursor`1.IsForwardOnly
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor only moves forward.

remarks.alert: must be immutable. Contracts of members depend upon it.

member.value: if the cursor only moves forward; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Linq.ICursor`1.CurrentIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the element in the sequence at which the cursor is positioned after is called.

remarks.para: starts and remains at 0 until it is changed by the method. A value of 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the end of an empty sequence. If the sequence generates one or more values, then 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the beginning of the sequence. Subscribing to a cursor that has not moved replays all values in the sequence, if any.

The valid range of values for changes depending upon whether the sequence has terminated. If the sequence has not terminated, then can be any value that is greater than or equal to zero, even if that value is greater than ; however, once the sequence has terminated, cannot be moved past one more than the . This final position indicates that the cursor is at the end of the sequence. Enumerating a cursor that is positioned at the end of the sequence causes only the termination notification to be yielded, without replaying any values.

If is moved past the latest element in the sequence, as indicated by the value of , then the existing values in the sequence will not be replayed to new subscriptions; furthermore, any new values with indices that are less than will also be excluded from new subscriptions.
remarks.alert: If the current index is positioned ahead of the latest element in the sequence and the sequence subsequently ends, then the current index must automatically be changed to + 1 to indicate that the current index is at the end of the sequence. Consumers can check whether has changed during the OnCompleted notification.

member.value: The zero-based index of the element in the sequence on which the cursor is positioned after is called; otherwise, -1.

member.name: P:System.Linq.ICursor`1.LatestIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence.
member.value: The zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence; -1 until the sequence produces an element, if any. If the sequence has terminated, then the value is the index of the last element in the sequence.

member.name: P:System.Linq.ICursor`1.AtEndOfSequence
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor is positioned at the end of the sequence.

remarks.alert: When returns it does not indicate that the sequence has not terminated. It only indicates that the cursor is not currently positioned at the end of the sequence, regardless of whether the sequence has actually terminated or not.

member.value: if the sequence has terminated and the cursor is currently positioned at the end of the sequence; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Linq.ICursor`1.IsSequenceTerminated
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the sequence has terminated.

remarks.alert: When returns it does not indicate that the cursor is at the end of the sequence. It only indicates that the sequence has terminated, regardless of whether the cursor is actually positioned at the end of the sequence or not.
must be immutable when it returns . Contracts of members depend upon it.

member.value: if the sequence has terminated; otherwise, .

member.name: T:Rxx.Parsers.ILookAheadParseResult`1
member.summary: Represents a possible result of a parse operation over a sequence, depending upon whether a subsequent parser matches.

remarks.para: This type of result is used by lazy quantifiers. It does not represent look-ahead as in the Regular Expression sense. That kind of look-ahead can be expressed using a normal SelectMany query by simply applying the NonGreedy operator to the first parser. That will effectively allow the first parser to look-ahead for a match from the current position of the cursor, without consuming the results. The second parser is then executed from the same starting position as the first parser, but only when the first parser matches.

Instead, this type of result allows quantifiers to end lazily by asking SelectMany if the second parser matches after each successful match from the quantified parser, starting at the end of the current match. Essentially, it's like adding NonGreedy to each individual match instead of adding it to the entire quantified parser. Behaviorally, it's a special kind of result that indicates to SelectMany to look ahead at the second parser and notify the result whether it's successful or not, without yielding.
remarks.alert: The implementation must only accept a single call, specifying to indicate that the look-ahead succeeded and that the parse result can be captured by the parser that generated it; otherwise, should be specified. The specified value must be buffered and replayed to all observers.

When developing custom parser operators, there is no need to use the implementation of . In other words, do not call Subscribe or OnCompleted. Look-aheads are handled by the infrastructure, so simply treat this type of result like a normal .

A function that receives an object from which a parser cursor can be obtained and returns a grammar defined as a LINQ query.
member.remarks: The recommended approach to defining an in-line query is to use query comprehension syntax, starting with a statement to bind the cursor parser to a query variable named next, followed by the definitions of zero or more individual grammar rules as statements, and finally the complete grammar as a parser query in terms of the previously defined rules projected as a statement.
member.returns: An enumerable sequence of matches.

member.remarks: The recommended approach to defining an in-line query is to use query comprehension syntax, starting with a statement to bind the cursor parser to a query variable named next, followed by the definitions of zero or more individual grammar rules as statements, and finally the complete grammar as a parser query in terms of the previously defined rules projected as a statement.
member.returns: An enumerable sequence of matches.

member.name: T:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1
member.summary: Represents a shared observable sequence that replays values from a current index that can be moved, along with support for optimized branching.

remarks.alert: The contracts of rely on some of the properties being immutable. The and properties must be immutable. Furthermore, the property must be until the sequence terminates, at which time it must return and then hold that value indefinitely.

member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.Move(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the current index of the cursor to the element at the specified number of elements forward or backward.
member.param: The number of elements to move after the current index if the specified count is positive or before the current index if the specified count is negative.

remarks.para: The specified may be a negative number only if is .
remarks.alert: If the specified is greater than the length from the current element to the latest element in the sequence, then the cursor must virtualize itself by skipping subsequent elements until the position of the cursor is reached.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.Branch
member.summary: Returns a new cursor that starts at the current position of this cursor and is tied to the lifetime of this cursor.

remarks.alert: provides a means for cursor authors to optimize branches so that they can share the same state.

member.returns: A new cursor that starts at the current position of this cursor.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.Subscribe(System.IObserver{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Notifies the provider that an observer is to receive the specified maximum number of OnNext notifications.

remarks.para: This overload to behaves similarly except that it has a parameter that specifies the maximum number of elements that may be pushed to the . Essentially, it provides an optimized alternative to .

The parameter applies to cursors because they typically will buffer data from the source sequence and replay it to subscribers, starting from the current index and continuing to the latest value that has been buffered. When a subscriber only wants to view a range of data, then is often added to the query to specify the number of notifications that are desired; however, the operator cannot cancel the notifications that are being replayed from the cursor, so it simply drops any additional notifications that exceed the specified limit. The specified will not observe the additional notifications, although the overhead of replaying an entire buffered sequence to the operator could have a noticeable impact on the performance of your code. By implementing , replayed notifications can be stopped when the specified is reached.

member.param: The object that is to receive notifications.
The maximum number of elements to be observed.
member.returns: The observer's interface that enables resources to be disposed.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.IsSynchronized
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor's methods and properties can be used concurrently by multiple threads.

remarks.alert: must be immutable. Contracts of members depend upon it.

member.value: if the cursor is safe for multi-threaded operations; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.IsForwardOnly
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor only moves forward.

remarks.alert: must be immutable. Contracts of members depend upon it.

member.value: if the cursor only moves forward; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.CurrentIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the element in the sequence at which the cursor is positioned after is called.

remarks.para: starts and remains at 0 until it is changed by the method. A value of 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the end of an empty sequence. If the sequence generates one or more values, then 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the beginning of the sequence. Subscribing to a cursor that has not moved replays all values in the sequence, if any.

The valid range of values for changes depending upon whether the sequence has terminated. If the sequence has not terminated, then can be any value that is greater than or equal to zero, even if that value is greater than ; however, once the sequence has terminated, cannot be moved past one more than the . This final position indicates that the cursor is at the end of the sequence. Calling on a cursor that is positioned at the end of the sequence causes only the termination notification to be pushed, without replaying any values.

If is moved past the latest element in the sequence, as indicated by the value of , then the existing values in the sequence will not be replayed to new subscriptions; furthermore, any new values with indices that are less than will also be excluded from new subscriptions.
remarks.alert: If the current index is positioned ahead of the latest element in the sequence and the sequence subsequently ends, then the current index must automatically be changed to + 1 to indicate that the current index is at the end of the sequence. Consumers can check whether has changed during the OnCompleted notification.

member.value: The zero-based index of the element in the sequence on which the cursor is positioned after is called; otherwise, -1.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.LatestIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence.
member.value: The zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence; -1 until the sequence produces an element, if any. If the sequence has terminated, then the value is the index of the last element in the sequence.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.AtEndOfSequence
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor is positioned at the end of the sequence.

remarks.alert: When returns it does not indicate that the sequence has not terminated. It only indicates that the cursor is not currently positioned at the end of the sequence, regardless of whether the sequence has actually terminated or not.

member.value: if the sequence has terminated and the cursor is currently positioned at the end of the sequence; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.IsSequenceTerminated
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the sequence has terminated.

remarks.alert: When returns it does not indicate that the cursor is at the end of the sequence. It only indicates that the sequence has terminated, regardless of whether the cursor is actually positioned at the end of the sequence or not.
must be immutable when it returns . Contracts of members depend upon it.

member.value: if the sequence has terminated; otherwise, .

member.name: P:System.Reactive.IObservableCursor`1.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor is disposed.
member.value: if the cursor is disposed; otherwise, .

member.summary: Applies the specified unambiguous parser grammar to generate matches.
member.typeparam: The type of the source elements.
The type of the elements that are generated from parsing the source elements.
member.param: The observable sequence to parse.
A function that receives an object from which a parser cursor can be obtained and returns a grammar defined as a LINQ query.
member.remarks: The recommended approach to defining an in-line query is to use query comprehension syntax, starting with a statement to bind the cursor parser to a query variable named next, followed by the definitions of zero or more individual grammar rules as statements, and finally the complete grammar as a parser query in terms of the previously defined rules projected as a statement.
member.returns: An observable sequence of matches.

member.name: M:System.IO.StreamExtensions.ToObservable``1(System.IO.Stream,System.IObservable{``0})
member.summary: Creates an observable sequence of bytes by asynchronously reading to the end of the specified each time the sequence notifies that additional data is available to be read and advances the position within the stream to the end.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the sequence that notifies when data is available to be read.
member.param: The object from which bytes are read as data becomes available.
An observable sequence that notifies when additional data is available to be read.
member.remarks: The generated sequence is intended to match the specified stream; however, this behavior depends on whether the stream is well-behaved and whether the stream is not being shared. Reading always starts from the current position of the stream. The stream is expected to increment its position when it's read. Each time that the sequence notifies that additional data is available, reading is expected to begin at the previous position in the stream, but if the stream is shared or it's not well-behaved, then the generated sequence may contain unexpected data.
member.returns: An observable sequence of byte arrays of a default maximum size read from the specified .

member.name: M:System.IO.StreamExtensions.ToObservableLines``1(System.IO.Stream,System.Text.Encoding,System.IObservable{``0})
member.summary: Creates an observable sequence by reading lines to the end of the specified each time the sequence notifies that additional text is available to be read and advances the position within the stream to the end.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the sequence that notifies when text is available to be read.
member.param: The object from which lines are read as they become available.
The character encoding to use.
An observable sequence that notifies when additional text is available to be read.

remarks.para: The sequence does not have to notify when new lines are available. It only must notify when new text is available, which may or may not have new lines. Characters that are read up to the end of the stream are automatically buffered until a new line sequence is encountered in a subsequent read. A consequence of this behavior is that if the stream does not end with a new line sequence and it's not going to receive any more text, then the last line will not be read until calls OnCompleted.

The generated sequence is intended to match the specified stream; however, this behavior depends on whether the stream is well-behaved and whether the stream is not being shared. Reading always starts from the current position of the stream. The stream is expected to increment its position when it's read. Each time that the sequence notifies that additional text is available, reading is expected to begin at the previous position in the stream, but if the stream is shared or it's not well-behaved, then the generated sequence may contain unexpected data.

member.returns: An observable sequence of lines read from the specified .

member.name: F:System.Linq.Cursor`1.firstElementIndex
member.summary: Stores the index offset, relative to the source sequence, of the first value in the list.
member.remarks: This field is used as part of a memory optimization in a forward-only cursor that allows elements to be removed when the cursor and all dependent branches have moved passed them, consequently offsetting the indexes in the list with respect to the actual source sequence.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Collect``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.IObservable{System.Reactive.CollectionModification{``0}})
member.summary: Concurrently populates a with elements from the first sequence while also handling changes from the second sequence of collection modifications, reconciling conflicts using the default equality comparer for .
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: The sequence from which the is initially populated.
The sequence from which collection notifications that modify the are received.

remarks.para: The sequence is subscribed to first, followed by the sequence on another thread. This order of subscription avoids a certain race condition that could otherwise allow an element that no longer exists to be added anyway, without receiving a corresponding Remove notification from the sequence.

The sequence is used to populate the initial state of the collection, under the assumption that the sequence does not provide notifications for elements that are considered to already exist; however, it may provide notifications for existing elements after it provides corresponding notifications for those elements, thus the sequence is processed concurrently while the collection is being populated by the sequence.
The sequence is given precedence for all race conditions and conflicts while the collection is being populated by the sequence. This process is refered to as reconciliation.

Reconciliation ends when either of the two sequences completes. It also ends upon the first notification to be received, because this indicates that there are no more existing elements. The remainder of the sequence is therefore ignored. If the sequence is still producing elements, then those elements must have been created recently and simply picked up by the sequence due to a race condition outside of the control of this method; however, the sequence is still expected to provide notifications for these new elements, so they will not be missed.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST provide a forward-only view of the source.
MUST ensure that element positions within the sequence are unique and absolute.
SHOULD finish observing all existing items and call OnCompleted.

remarks.para: Therefore, if an element is created after the sequence has passed the element's absolute position, it will not be included in the sequence; however, a well-behaving sequence will include it. Furthermore, if an element is observed by the sequence and then subsequently deleted and recreated, it will not be observed a second time.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST generate notifications in a logical order.
SHOULD provide a dynamic, real-time view that includes all changes to the source.

remarks.para: An example of a logical order for the sequence is to include an notification followed by a notification when an element has been added and subsequently removed. An example of an illogical order for this scenario is to include a notification before an notification, which does not accurately reflect the state of changes to the source.
remarks.alert: An illogical ordering of notifications in the sequence voids all gaurantees that the reconciliation process makes about the state of the collection when the sequence completes, and also voids all gaurantees about the active state of the collection thereafter.

member.returns: A that receives the elements from the specified sequences.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Collect``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.IObservable{System.Reactive.CollectionModification{``0}},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{``0})
member.summary: Concurrently populates a with elements from the first sequence while also handling changes from the second sequence of collection modifications, reconciling conflicts using the specified equality comparer for .
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: The sequence from which the is initially populated.
The sequence from which collection notifications that modify the are received.
The object that compares two instances of for equality and generates a hash code that is suitable for use when keying a dictionary.

remarks.para: The sequence is subscribed to first, followed by the sequence on another thread. This order of subscription avoids a certain race condition that could otherwise allow an element that no longer exists to be added anyway, without receiving a corresponding Remove notification from the sequence.

The sequence is used to populate the initial state of the collection, under the assumption that the sequence does not provide notifications for elements that are considered to already exist; however, it may provide notifications for existing elements after it provides corresponding notifications for those elements, thus the sequence is processed concurrently while the collection is being populated by the sequence.
The sequence is given precedence for all race conditions and conflicts while the collection is being populated by the sequence. This process is refered to as reconciliation.

Reconciliation ends when either of the two sequences completes. It also ends upon the first notification to be received, because this indicates that there are no more existing elements. The remainder of the sequence is therefore ignored. If the sequence is still producing elements, then those elements must have been created recently and simply picked up by the sequence due to a race condition outside of the control of this method; however, the sequence is still expected to provide notifications for these new elements, so they will not be missed.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST provide a forward-only view of the source.
MUST ensure that element positions within the sequence are unique and absolute.
SHOULD finish observing all existing items and call OnCompleted.

remarks.para: Therefore, if an element is created after the sequence has passed the element's absolute position, it will not be included in the sequence; however, a well-behaving sequence will include it. Furthermore, if an element is observed by the sequence and then subsequently deleted and recreated, it will not be observed a second time.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST generate notifications in a logical order.
SHOULD provide a dynamic, real-time view that includes all changes to the source.

remarks.para: An example of a logical order for the sequence is to include an notification followed by a notification when an element has been added and subsequently removed. An example of an illogical order for this scenario is to include a notification before an notification, which does not accurately reflect the state of changes to the source.
remarks.alert: An illogical ordering of notifications in the sequence voids all gaurantees that the reconciliation process makes about the state of the collection when the sequence completes, and also voids all gaurantees about the active state of the collection thereafter.

member.returns: A that receives the elements from the specified sequences.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.CombineLatest``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.IObservable{``0}})
member.summary: Merges two or more observable sequences into one observable sequence of lists, each containing the latest values from all observable sequences whenever one of the sequences produces an element.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: An enumerable sequence containing two or more observable sequences to be merged.

remarks.para: All of the observable sequences must produce at least one element; otherwise, the generated sequence will be empty. Furthermore, if an observable sequence produces more than one element before each of the other observable sequences have produced their first elements, then all of the older elements are discarded and will not be included in the generated sequence. Only the latest elements from each sequence are included.

The latest value of an observable sequence is always located in the generated lists at the same index in which that sequence is located in the outer sequence. For example, the values from the first observable sequence in the outer sequence will always be at index zero (0) in the lists that are generated.

member.returns: An observable sequence containing the result of combining the latest elements of all sources into lists.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.CombineLatest``1(System.IObservable{System.IObservable{``0}})
member.summary: Merges two or more observable sequences into one observable sequence of lists, each containing the latest values from the latest consecutive observable sequences whenever one of the sequences produces an element.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: An observable sequence containing two or more observable sequences to be merged.

remarks.para: At least two consecutive observable sequences from the beginning of the outer observable sequence must produce at least one element; otherwise, the generated sequence will be empty. Furthermore, if an observable sequence produces more than one element before each of the consecutive observable sequences have produced their first elements, then all of the older elements are discarded and will not be included in the generated sequence. Only the latest elements from each of the consecutive sequences are included. As new sequences arrive, the size of the generated lists are increased to accomodate them if they start producing values.

The latest value of an observable sequence is always located in the generated lists at the same index in which that sequence is located in the outer sequence. For example, the values from the first observable sequence in the outer sequence will always be at index zero (0) in the lists that are generated. Furthermore, once a generated list contains the value for a particular observable sequence, all subsequent lists will also contain the latest value for that sequence. As a result, the number of items in the generated lists may stay the same or grow when new observable sequences arrive, but the size of the lists will never shrink.

member.returns: An observable sequence containing the result of combining the latest elements of all sources into lists.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Serve``1(System.Func{System.IObservable{``0}})
member.summary: Concurrently invokes the specified factory to create observables as fast and often as possible and subscribes to all of them up to the default maximum concurrency. (See the remarks section for important details about the concurrent behavior.)
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: A function that returns observables.

remarks.para: is similar to except that notifications may be sent concurrently. Its behavior is therefore more suitable for hosting environments that must service multiple requests concurrently without blocking during observations.
remarks.alert: The observable that is returned may call OnNext concurrently. This behavior violates an important contract in Rx. The Rx Design Guidelines document states that Rx operators assume notifications are sent in a serialized fashion. The only methods that do not conflict with this guideline and are safe to call on the observable are Subscribe and Synchronize. Do not attempt to use any other Rx operators unless the observable is synchronized first.

member.returns: A concurrent observable sequence.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Serve``1(System.Func{System.IObservable{``0}},System.Func{System.Exception,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Concurrently invokes the specified factory to create observables as fast and often as possible and subscribes to all of them up to the default maximum concurrency. (See the remarks section for important details about the concurrent behavior.)
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: A function that returns observables.
Determines whether an error should fault the entire observable sequence.

remarks.para: is similar to except that notifications may be sent concurrently. Its behavior is therefore more suitable for hosting environments that must service multiple requests concurrently without blocking during observations.
remarks.alert: The observable that is returned may call OnNext concurrently. This behavior violates an important contract in Rx. The Rx Design Guidelines document states that Rx operators assume notifications are sent in a serialized fashion. The only methods that do not conflict with this guideline and are safe to call on the observable are Subscribe and Synchronize. Do not attempt to use any other Rx operators unless the observable is synchronized first.
remarks.para: Furthermore, provides an parameter that allows the caller to decide whether an is fatal and should fault the entire sequence. This function should return to indicate that an has been handled, thus preventing the sequence from being faulted; otherwise, return to fault the sequence and halt processing as soon as possible. In the latter case, the is then passed to the observer of the sequence as is the normal behavior in Rx.

member.returns: A concurrent observable sequence.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Serve``1(System.Func{System.IObservable{``0}},System.Int32)
member.summary: Concurrently invokes the specified factory to create observables as fast and often as possible and subscribes to all of them up to the specified maximum concurrency. (See the remarks section for important details about the concurrent behavior.)
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: A function that returns observables.
The maximum number of observables to be subscribed simultaneously.

remarks.para: is similar to except that notifications may be sent concurrently. Its behavior is therefore more suitable for hosting environments that must service multiple requests concurrently without blocking during observations.
remarks.alert: The observable that is returned may call OnNext concurrently. This behavior violates an important contract in Rx. The Rx Design Guidelines document states that Rx operators assume notifications are sent in a serialized fashion. The only methods that do not conflict with this guideline and are safe to call on the observable are Subscribe and Synchronize. Do not attempt to use any other Rx operators unless the observable is synchronized first.

member.returns: A concurrent observable sequence.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Serve``1(System.Func{System.IObservable{``0}},System.Int32,System.Func{System.Exception,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Concurrently invokes the specified factory to create observables as fast and often as possible and subscribes to all of them up to the specified maximum concurrency. (See the remarks section for important details about the concurrent behavior.)
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: A function that returns observables.
The maximum number of observables to be subscribed simultaneously.
Determines whether an error should fault the entire observable sequence.

remarks.para: is similar to except that notifications may be sent concurrently. Its behavior is therefore more suitable for hosting environments that must service multiple requests concurrently without blocking during observations.
remarks.alert: The observable that is returned may call OnNext concurrently. This behavior violates an important contract in Rx. The Rx Design Guidelines document states that Rx operators assume notifications are sent in a serialized fashion. The only methods that do not conflict with this guideline and are safe to call on the observable are Subscribe and Synchronize. Do not attempt to use any other Rx operators unless the observable is synchronized first.
remarks.para: Furthermore, provides an parameter that allows the caller to decide whether an is fatal and should fault the entire sequence. This function should return to indicate that an has been handled, thus preventing the sequence from being faulted; otherwise, return to fault the sequence and halt processing as soon as possible. In the latter case, the is then passed to the observer of the sequence as is the normal behavior in Rx.

member.returns: A concurrent observable sequence.

member.summary: Concurrently populates a with elements from the first sequence while also handling changes from the second sequence of collection modifications, reconciling conflicts using the default equality comparer for .
member.typeparam: The type of the keys in the dictionary.
The type of the values in the dictionary.
member.param: The sequence from which the is initially populated.
A function that maps values from the sequence to keys.
The sequence from which collection notifications that modify the are received.

remarks.para: The sequence is subscribed to first, followed by the sequence on another thread. This order of subscription avoids a certain race condition that could otherwise allow an element that no longer exists to be added anyway, without receiving a corresponding Remove notification from the sequence.

The sequence is used to populate the initial state of the collection, under the assumption that the sequence does not provide notifications for elements that are considered to already exist; however, it may provide notifications for existing elements after it provides corresponding notifications for those elements, thus the sequence is processed concurrently while the collection is being populated by the sequence.
The sequence is given precedence for all race conditions and conflicts while the collection is being populated by the sequence. This process is refered to as reconciliation.

Reconciliation ends when either of the two sequences completes. It also ends upon the first notification to be received, because this indicates that there are no more existing elements. The remainder of the sequence is therefore ignored. If the sequence is still producing elements, then those elements must have been created recently and simply picked up by the sequence due to a race condition outside of the control of this method; however, the sequence is still expected to provide notifications for these new elements, so they will not be missed.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST provide a forward-only view of the source.
MUST ensure that element positions within the sequence are unique and absolute.
SHOULD finish observing all existing items and call OnCompleted.

remarks.para: Therefore, if an element is created after the sequence has passed the element's absolute position, it will not be included in the sequence; however, a well-behaving sequence will include it. Furthermore, if an element is observed by the sequence and then subsequently deleted and recreated, it will not be observed a second time.
A well-behaving sequence:

item.description: MUST generate notifications in a logical order.
SHOULD provide a dynamic, real-time view that includes all changes to the source.

remarks.para: An example of a logical order for the sequence is to include an notification followed by a notification when an element has been added and subsequently removed. An example of an illogical order for this scenario is to include a notification before an notification, which does not accurately reflect the state of changes to the source.
remarks.alert: An illogical ordering of notifications in the sequence voids all gaurantees that the reconciliation process makes about the state of the collection when the sequence completes, and also voids all gaurantees about the active state of the collection thereafter.

member.returns: A that receives the elements from the specified sequences.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.RetryConsecutive``1(System.IObservable{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Repeats the source observable sequence when it throws consecutively until it produces a value, successfully terminates or the specified count has been reached and pairs it with an error channel.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: The observable to be repeated.
The maximum number of times to retry the sequence consecutively when it's faulted.
member.remarks: is appropriate when permanent recovery is required for sequences that experience ephemeral consecutive errors at unpredictable intervals, such as those originating from network streams. For example, it can produce a sequence that automatically reconnects upon consecutive network failures up to the specified number of times; furthermore, if the sequence is able to successfully generate a value after an error, then the retry count is reset for subsequent consecutive failures.
member.returns: The specified observable sequence with an error channel.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Prime``1(System.Reactive.Subjects.IConnectableObservable{``0})
member.summary: Connects the specified connectable observable sequence upon the first subscription and never disconnects.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: The connectable observable sequence to be connected upon the first subscription.

remarks.para: It may be easier to think of priming as creating a warm observable, instead of a cold or hot observable. A cold observable allows subscription side-effects to occur each time, whereas a hot observable does not. A hot observable is already active before the first subscription, whereas a warm observable is not.

member.returns: The specified observable sequence primed for use.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Consume``2(System.IObservable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Maybe{``1}})
member.summary: Generates a sequence using the producer/consumer pattern by iteratively calling a consumer function when data is available.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
The type of the data in the generated sequence.
member.param: Indicates when data becomes available from one or more producers.
A function that is called iteratively to generate values from out-of-band data.

remarks.para: The purpose of the sequence is simply to notify the consumer when data becomes available in out-of-band storage. The data in the sequence provides additional information to the consumer, but it does not have to be the actual data produced for the consumer.
The function is called iteratively when data becomes available, until it returns . All non-empty values that are returned are concatenated into the generated sequence.

ensures that there is always one active iterator over the function when the sequence notifies that data is available; however, it's not necessarily called for every value in the sequence. It is only called if the previous iteration has completed; otherwise, the current notification is ignored. This ensures that only one consumer is active at any given time, but it also means that the function is not guaranteed to receive every value in the sequence; therefore, the function must read data from out-of-band storage instead; e.g., from a shared stream or queue.

The function may also be called when data is not available. For example, if the current consuming iterator completes and additional notifications from the were received, then is called again to check whether new data was missed. This avoids a race condition between the sequence and reading shared data. If no data is available when is called, then should be returned and will not be called again until another notification is observed from the .
remarks.alert: Producers and the single active consumer are intended to access shared objects concurrently, yet it remains their responsibility to ensure thread-safety. The Consume operator cannot do so without breaking concurrency. For example, a producer/consumer implementation that uses an in-memory queue must manually ensure that reads and writes to the queue are thread-safe.
remarks.para: Multiple producers are supported. Simply create an observable sequence for each producer that notifies when data is generated, merge them together using the operator, and use the merged observable as the argument in the Consume operator.

Multiple consumers are supported by calling Consume once and then calling multiple times on the cold observable that is returned. Just be sure that the sequence is hot so that each subscription will consume based on the same producers' notifications.

member.returns: An observable sequence that is the concatenation of the values returned by the function.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Consume``2(System.IObservable{``0},System.IObservable{``1})
member.summary: Generates a sequence using the producer/consumer pattern.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
The type of the data in the generated sequence.
member.param: Indicates when data becomes available from one or more producers.
An observable that is generated from out-of-band data.

remarks.para: The purpose of the sequence is simply to notify when data becomes available in out-of-band storage. The data in the sequence is ignored.

ensures that there is always an active subscription to the sequence when the sequence notifies that data is available; however, a new subscription is not necessarily created for every value in the sequence. is only called if the previous subscription has completed; otherwise, the current notification is ignored. This ensures that only one consumer is active at any given time and that all available data has a chance to be read.

A new subscription may also be created when data is not available. For example, if the current subscription completes and additional notifications from the were received, then another subscription is created to check whether new data was missed. This avoids a race condition between the sequence and the consumer's completion notification. If no data is available for the new subscription, then an empty sequence should be generated and a new subscription will not be created again until another notification is observed from the .
remarks.alert: Producers and the single active consumer are intended to access shared objects concurrently, yet it remains their responsibility to ensure thread-safety. The Consume operator cannot do so without breaking concurrency. For example, a producer/consumer implementation that uses an in-memory queue must manually ensure that reads and writes to the queue are thread-safe.
remarks.para: Multiple producers are supported. Simply create an observable sequence for each producer that notifies when data is generated, merge them together using the operator, and use the merged observable as the argument in the Consume operator.

Multiple consumers are supported by calling Consume once and then calling multiple times on the cold observable that is returned. Just be sure that the sequence is hot so that each subscription will consume based on the same producers' notifications.

member.returns: An observable sequence that is the concatenation of all subscriptions to the observable.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Consume``2(System.IObservable{``0},System.Func{``0,System.IObservable{``1}})

remarks.para: The purpose of the sequence is simply to notify the consumer when out-of-band data becomes available. The data in the sequence provides additional information to the function, but it does not have to be the actual data being produced.

The function is not necessarily called for every value in the sequence. It is only called if the previous consumer's observable has completed; otherwise, the current notification is ignored. This ensures that only one consumer is active at any given time, but it also means that the function is not guaranteed to receive every value in the sequence; therefore, the function must read data from out-of-band storage instead; e.g., from a shared stream or queue.

The function may also be called when data is not available. For example, if the current consuming observable completes and additional notifications from the were received, then is called again to check whether new data was missed. This avoids a race condition between the sequence and the consuming observable's completion notification. If no data is available when is called, then an empty sequence should be returned and will not be called again until another notification is observed from the .
remarks.alert: Producers and the single active consumer are intended to access shared objects concurrently, yet it remains their responsibility to ensure thread-safety. The Consume operator cannot do so without breaking concurrency. For example, a producer/consumer implementation that uses an in-memory queue must manually ensure that reads and writes to the queue are thread-safe.
remarks.para: Multiple producers are supported. Simply create an observable sequence for each producer that notifies when data is generated, merge them together using the operator, and use the merged observable as the argument in the Consume operator.

Multiple consumers are supported by calling Consume once and then calling multiple times on the cold observable that is returned. Just be sure that the sequence is hot so that each subscription will consume based on the same producers' notifications.

member.summary: Avoids when combining a large number of sequential SelectMany operations. This extra info is used by the All parser combinator to elliminate extra branching on the last element of each sequence. See the AllParser.Parse method for details.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Zip``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.IObservable{``0}})
member.summary: Merges two or more observable sequences into one observable sequence of lists by combining their elements in a pairwise fashion.
member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.
member.param: An enumerable sequence containing two or more observable sequences to be merged.

remarks.para: All of the observable sequences must produce at least one element; otherwise, the generated sequence will be empty. Furthermore, if an observable sequence produces more than one element before each of the other observable sequences have produced their first elements, then all of the elements will be enqueued for future pairing. No elements are discarded.

The latest value of an observable sequence is always located in the generated lists at the same index in which that sequence is located in the outer sequence. For example, the values from the first observable sequence in the outer sequence will always be at index zero (0) in the lists that are generated.

member.returns: An observable sequence containing the result of pairwise combining the elements of all sources into lists.

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Linq.Observable2.Zip``1(System.IObservable{System.IObservable{``0}})

Furthermore, if an observable sequence produces more than one element before each of the other observable sequences have produced their first elements, then all of the elements will be enqueued for future pairing. No elements are discarded.

The latest value of an observable sequence is always located in the generated lists at the same index in which that sequence is located in the outer sequence. For example, the values from the first observable sequence in the outer sequence will always be at index zero (0) in the lists that are generated.

member.returns: An observable sequence containing the result of pairwise combining the elements of all sources into lists.

member.summary: Stores the index offset, relative to the source sequence, of the first value in the list.
member.remarks: This field is used as part of a memory optimization in a forward-only cursor that allows elements to be removed when the cursor and all dependent branches have moved passed them, consequently offsetting the indexes in the list with respect to the actual source sequence.

member.name: T:System.Reactive.Subjects.CursorSubject`1
member.summary: Represents an observer and a replaying observable sequence with a current index that can be moved.

remarks.para: A cursor is a moveable pointer over an immutable sequence. This differs from the concept of a , which is a moveable pointer over a mutable buffer. Mutability is a key difference; it means that moving the position of a stream backward allows you to overwrite the data from that position to the end of the stream, while moving the position of a cursor backward only changes the index in the sequence from which data is replayed to new subscribers. In other words, data written to a stream is always inserted at the current position, but data observed by a cursor is always appended to the end of the buffered sequence.

Furthermore, the position of a stream is shared between reads and writes, but the position of a cursor is not. A cursor's position is only used by reads (subscribers) and is entirely independent of writes. Subscribing to a cursor replays the data in the sequence from the current index to the end; however, the current index is not moved at all. Changing the index later has no effect on existing subscriptions, but changing the position of a stream would certainly effect existing readers.
provides a superset of the functionality that is provided by , and . Each of these subjects could be implemented in terms of by moving the after calling , as necessary.

member.typeparam: The object that provides notification information.

member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.
member.param: if the cursor can only be moved forward; otherwise, .

member.summary: Constructs a new instance of the class.
member.param: if the cursor can only be moved forward; otherwise, .

Specifies whether a forward-only cursor is allowed to truncate the buffered sequence, if necessary, whenever a branch is moved. In the future, it may control other kinds of branch optimizations as well. The default value is .

member.name: M:System.Reactive.Subjects.CursorSubject`1.Subscribe(System.IObserver{`0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Notifies the provider that an observer is to receive the specified maximum number of OnNext notifications.

remarks.para: This overload to behaves similarly except that it has a parameter that specifies the maximum number of elements that may be pushed to the . Essentially, it provides an optimized alternative to .

The parameter applies to cursors because they typically will buffer data from the source sequence and replay it to subscribers, starting from the current index and continuing to the latest value that has been buffered. When a subscriber only wants to view a range of data, then is often added to the query to specify the number of notifications that are desired; however, the operator cannot cancel the notifications that are being replayed from the cursor, so it simply drops any additional notifications that exceed the specified limit. The specified will not observe the additional notifications, although the overhead of replaying an entire buffered sequence to the operator could have a noticeable impact on the performance of your code. By implementing , replayed notifications can be stopped when the specified is reached.

member.param: The object that is to receive notifications.
The maximum number of elements to be observed.
member.returns: The observer's interface that enables resources to be disposed.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.Subjects.CursorSubject`1.CurrentIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the element in the sequence at which the cursor is positioned after is called.

remarks.para: starts and remains at 0 until it is changed by the method. A value of 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the end of an empty sequence. If the sequence generates one or more values, then 0 indicates that the cursor is positioned at the beginning of the sequence. Subscribing to a cursor that has not moved replays all values in the sequence, if any.

The valid range of values for changes depending upon whether the sequence has terminated. If the sequence has not terminated, then can be any value that is greater than or equal to zero, even if that value is greater than ; however, once the sequence has terminated, cannot be moved past one more than the . This final position indicates that the cursor is at the end of the sequence. Calling Subscribe on a cursor that is positioned at the end of the sequence causes only the termination notification to be pushed, without replaying any values.

If is moved past the latest element in the sequence, as indicated by the value of , then the existing values in the sequence will not be replayed to new subscriptions; furthermore, any new values with indices that are less than will also be excluded from new subscriptions.

If the current index is positioned ahead of the latest element in the sequence and the sequence subsequently ends, then the current index is automatically changed to + 1 to indicate that the current index is at the end of the sequence. Consumers can check whether has changed during the OnCompleted notification.

member.value: The zero-based index of the element in the sequence on which the cursor is positioned after is called; otherwise, -1.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.Subjects.CursorSubject`1.LatestIndex
member.summary: Gets the zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence.
member.value: The zero-based index of the last known element in the sequence; -1 until the sequence produces an element, if any. If the sequence has terminated, then the value is the index of the last element in the sequence.

member.name: P:System.Reactive.Subjects.CursorSubject`1.AtEndOfSequence
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the cursor is positioned at the end of the sequence.

remarks.alert: When returns it does not indicate that the sequence has not terminated. It only indicates that the cursor is not currently positioned at the end of the sequence, regardless of whether the sequence has actually terminated or not.

member.value: if the sequence has terminated and the cursor is currently positioned at the end of the sequence; otherwise, .

member.value: if the sequence has terminated; otherwise, .

member.name: M:System.Windows.FrameworkElementExtensions.GetViewModel(System.Windows.FrameworkElement)
member.summary: Gets the object that is currently attached to the specified .
member.remarks: actually returns the value of the property of the specified , whether or not it represents a view model object. This may change in a future version.
member.param: The from which the attachment will be returned.
member.returns: The object that is currently attached to the specified .

member.name: M:System.Windows.FrameworkElementExtensions.SetViewModel(System.Windows.FrameworkElement,System.Func{System.Object})
member.summary: Attaches a view model returned by the specified function to the of the specified each time that the is loaded, and detaches the current view model each time that the is unloaded.

remarks.para: allows the element's to be assigned to different objects or view models after a view model is attached. When a different object or view model is assigned, the current view model is permanently detached and the element's events are no longer tracked for the specified . To reassign the factory to the , call again.
The factory can return the same view model instance every time that it's called or it can create new view models. The factory can also return .
remarks.alert: Do not return the same view model instance more than once if it implements ; otherwise, the view model will be disposed the first time that it's detached, which may cause problems if it's reattached.
remarks.para: The objects returned by the factory do not have to derive from any particular base class or implement any particular interfaces; however, a couple of special interfaces are supported to provide additional functionality. If an object implements , then its method is called when the object is detached from the . If an object implements , then its and methods are called when appropriate. Implementations for both of these interfaces is provided by the base class.

member.param: The to which a view model will be attached.
A function that returns view model objects or .

member.name: T:Rxx.ViewModel
member.summary: Represents a attachment that may provide binding targets for properties and events, and controls the lifetime of its composited resources by permanently disposing of them when the is unloaded.

remarks.name: Silverlight
remarks.para: A view model provides a decoupled container for the state and behaviors on which a user interface (UI) depends. State and behaviors are typically represented in view models as targets for property and event bindings in the UI, without specific knowledge of the type or layout of the UI to which they're bound.

Classic view model base classes aren't designed specifically for reactive programming with , making them somewhat awkward to use in conjunction with observables. Property bindings with , and event bindings with are quite useful for decoupling a UI from its reusable state and behaviors, but they make reactive programming difficult because we must first convert them into observable sequences to take advantage of the capabilities of the Rx declarative programming model and LINQ.

does not implement because it targets a reactive programming model instead. To bind to a reactive property, define a DependencyProperty or implement yourself. To create a reactive command, simply return an instance of , then use a UI binding as you normally would to an .

All of the aforementioned solutions use types that implement , which makes it possible to define complex reactive queries among the different states and behaviors that are encapsulated by the view model.

Furthermore, subscribing to an observable sequence yields an artifact that represents the subscription. It has a logical lifetime that is the lifetime of the UI to which the view model is attached. Since the cancelation and disposal model of Rx is explicit to support fire-and-forget scenarios, often it's required to composite a view model's subscriptions and dispose of them when the UI is no longer needed, such as when it's unloaded. Take a dialog window for example, which may create subscriptions to observable sequences that must be canceled and released when the dialog is closed.

supports this by offering a composited collection of disposables that have the same lifetime as the to which the view model is attached. When the event is raised, all of the view model's disposables are disposed, so if subscriptions to observable sequences are added to the disposables collection they are cancelled and freed in a determinstic manner that corresponds directly to the lifetime of the UI.

Another common occurence when authoring view models is to subscribe to new observable sequences when the UI element first loads. facilitates this by providing an method that derived classes can override. returns a sequence of objects that are automatically added to the composited disposables collection of the view model. This makes it possible to subscribe to one or more observable sequences in an iterator block by simply yielding each subscription as a result. The subscriptions yielded are automatically disposed when the UI is unloaded.
remarks.alert: To attach a to a object, first define a class that derives from . Then use the method and return a new instance of your class within the factory argument, or use the attached property in XAML and set it to the of your class.
